awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Spatial-Mode Entanglement and Spatial-Mode-Selective Quantum Frequency Conversion in Few-Mode Fibers
awd_abstract_narration:
Optical fiber loss limits the rate of data transmission of long-distance quantum communication links, which are essential for secure information exchange and future quantum cloud computing. The only way to scale up the quantum communication rate is by increasing the number of degrees of freedom (modes) used by the transmitted photons. While polarization and frequency degrees of freedom have already been extensively explored, encoding the quantum information into the spatial modes (beam profiles) propagating in low-loss few-mode fibers has received little attention so far. This project aims to change this situation and open the spatial degrees of freedom for quantum communications by implementing encoders and decoders of spatial quantum information directly inside the fiber. 
Opening up a large number of spatial degrees of freedom will dramatically increase quantum communication rates and enable many future long-distance quantum networking applications. In addition, the developed spatial-mode selection technology could find its use also in classical telecommunications, e.g., in mode demultiplexing or in transfer of information between spatial and frequency modes. This project will train two students in nonlinear optics, quantum information processing, and optical communications. UTA is a minority-serving institution, and we will stimulate the interest in photonics from undergraduates and K-12 students via Open Lab events and visually-appealing demos.


Technical description
The goal of this exploratory project is to realize two key functions necessary for transmitting and receiving quantum information over spatially-multimode or few-mode optical fibers - the spatially-entangled photon-pair generation and spatial-mode-selective quantum frequency conversion - directly in a few-mode fiber (FMF) by means of inter-modal four-wave mixing. By employing pumps in two FMF modes, we will generate a signal-idler photon pair in these two orthogonal spatial modes. The FMF phase-matching conditions will enable two simultaneous FWM processes driven by two-wavelength pumps in each of the modes, which can be adapted to realize both functions mentioned above. Implementation of this spatial-quantum-information-processing functionality directly in FMF, unlike the previous approaches relying on second-order nonlinearity in exotic multimode waveguides, eliminates any coupling loss and crosstalk and utilizes the FMF medium that is already available commercially and is also widely customizable by a number of vendors and research institutions. This work could have a transformative impact on high-capacity quantum communications by enabling spatially-multimode-fiber-based quantum links.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for award ECCS-1937860

Optical fiber loss limits the rate of data transmission of long-distance quantum communication links, which are essential for secure information exchange and future quantum cloud computing. The only way to scale up the quantum communication rate is by increasing the number of degrees of freedom (modes) used by the transmitted photons. While polarization and frequency degrees of freedom have already been extensively explored, encoding the quantum information into the spatial modes (beam profiles) propagating in low-loss few-mode fibers has received little attention so far.

This project's aim has been to change this situation and open the spatial degrees of freedom for quantum communications by implementing encoders and decoders of spatial quantum information directly inside the fiber.

More specifically, this exploratory project has demonstrated the feasibility of implementing two key functions necessary for transmitting and receiving quantum information over spatially-multimode or few-mode optical fibers -- the spatially-entangled photon-pair generation and spatial-mode-selective quantum frequency conversion -- directly in a few-mode fiber (FMF) by means of inter-modal four-wave mixing (IM-FWM). Implementation of this spatial-quantum-information-processing functionality directly in FMF, unlike the previous approaches relying on second-order nonlinearity in exotic multimode waveguides, eliminates any coupling loss and crosstalk and utilizes the FMF medium that is already available commercially and is also widely customizable by a number of vendors and research institutions. This work could have a transformative impact on high-capacity quantum communications by enabling spatially-multimode-fiber-based quantum links.

In the first thrust area of this project, we have realized phase-matching conditions that enable two simultaneous IM-FWM processes driven by two-wavelength pumps in each of two modes of the FMF (fundamental LP00 and first-order LP11 modes in our case). Each of these processes individually converts a signal beam in one of these two modes to a fixed mode at a new wavelength. Simultaneously, these two processes can selectively convert any superposition of the two signal modes to the new frequency. We have experimentally implemented the two simultaneous IM-FWM processes with classical-level signals and demonstrated mode-selective frequency conversion efficiencies of about -40 dB and crosstalk levels below -20 dB.

In the second thrust area of this project, another set of two simultaneous IM-FWM processes has been used to produce spatially-correlated signal and idler beam pairs. One of these processes creates signal photons in LP00 mode and idler photons in LP11 mode, while the other creates signal photons in LP11 mode and idler photons in LP00 mode. For input classical-level signals in an arbitrary superposition of these two modes, we have experimentally demonstrated that, when used simultaneously, the two IM-FWM processes produce an idler beam in the spatial mode orthogonal to that of the input signal. Conversion efficiencies of about -43 dB and mode selectivity better than 19 dB have been observed. When no input signal is present, these processes are expected to generate spatially-entangled signal and idler beams. We have further extended this experiment to the generation of spatially-correlated signal and idler beams in LP11a, LP11b mode space that is compatible with orbital-angular momentum encoding.

We have also developed design criteria and key parameters for the future few-mode fibers optimized for highly-efficient spatial-mode-selective frequency conversion and spatial-mode-entangled photon-pair generation.

Opening up a large number of spatial degrees of freedom will dramatically increase quantum communication rates and enable many future long-distance quantum networking applications. In addition, the developed spatial-mode selection technology could find its use in classical telecommunications, e.g., in mode demultiplexing or in transfer of information between spatial and frequency modes. 

This research produced 2 published journal papers, 9 papers at peer-reviewed conferences, and 1 Ph.D. dissertation.

This project has provided full or partial support for 2 Ph.D. students and 1 undergraduate student at the University of Texas at Arlington. The students have acquired the skills in operating state-of-the-art optical test and measurement equipment, fusion splicers, designing optical and electronic hardware, and writing data acquisition and processing software. Most importantly, they have learned to work together as a team.
